descriptionSet.description: A portrait of a European woman in eastern dresses and jewellery.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

titleSet.title: Eid postcard showing a western woman

hra:item.hra:value: description-en: A portrait of a European woman in eastern dresses and jewellery. (gs)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The European images on these Eid cards are not always utterly out of context. In fact the printed Urdu messages on the address side often try to bridge the gap, especially by using romantic idioms when showing the picture of famous European actresses or dancers. For instance in one card, a poetic reference for Eid greetings between 'ashiq (lover) and ma'shuq (beloved) is made for a photograph of an unidentified European dancer/actress. (Yousuf Saeed)(gs)
explanatory comments/crosstagging: The verses read: Mere yahon ko mubarak Eid ho; Ghamgusaron ko mubarak Eid ho; Ashiq-o-mashuq, rind-o-paarsa; Aaj charon ko mubarak Eid ho (on backside?) () (ma)

related literature: Mathur, Saloni, "Wanted Native Views: Collecting colonial postcards of India," in Antionette Burton (ed.) Gender, Sexuality and Colonial Modernities, New York: Routledge, 1999, 95-115. (gs)
related literature: Patterson, Steven, Postcards from the Raj, Patterns of Prejudice, Volume 40, Number 2, Routledge, May 2006, 142-158; also see Saloni Mathur, 1999. (gs)
related hyperlink: Saeed, Yousuf 2011. "Eid Mubarak: Cross-cultural Image Exchange in Muslim South Asia." http://www.tasveergharindia.net/cmsdesk/essay/117/index_1.html last accessed 2011-04-06 (gs)
